explanation:
The correct translation requires moving \( +4 \) units horizontally (right) and \( +2 \) units vertically (up).  
The student instead calculated \( -4 \) units horizontally (left) and \( -2 \) units vertically (down).  
The error stems from misinterpreting the sign of the directional changes: they treated the required positive horizontal and vertical shifts as negative directions.  
This reversal directly corresponds to confusing the standard coordinate system, where right/up are positive, with an inverted system where left/down are mistakenly assumed as the default positive directions.  
The error is distinct from quadrant-related confusion (which involves coordinate signs) or vector component notation issues, as the student correctly identified the magnitude of movement but inverted both axes.  
The flaw is isolated to direction assignment, not the magnitude or coordinate plane orientation.
